transcript:
Therapist: You mentioned that using the Coping Card helped you get out of your head for a bit. That's a great observation. When we're caught up in negative thoughts, it can be really helpful to shift our focus to something else, even if it's just temporary. What was it like for you to take that walk outside or do the quick art sketch?

Patient: It was definitely a nice break from all the negative thoughts swirling around in my head. When I went for the walk, I tried to focus on my surroundings - the trees, the birds, the fresh air. It didn't make my problems disappear, but it gave me a bit of relief. And with the sketch, even though it wasn't my best work, it felt good to just create something without putting too much pressure on myself.

Therapist: That's really important - giving yourself permission to create without the pressure of perfection. It sounds like both the walk and the sketch allowed you to experience a different emotional state, even if briefly. That's a key part of managing low moods - finding ways to shift our emotional state, even in small ways.

Patient: Yeah, I guess I never really thought about it that way. It's not about making the negative feelings go away completely, but more about giving myself a break from them.

Therapist: Exactly. And the more we practice giving ourselves those breaks, the more we build up our emotional resilience. It's like a muscle we can strengthen over time. I'm wondering if we could spend some time now exploring some additional coping strategies you could add to your toolbox for managing those low moods and negative thoughts.

Patient: That would be great. I'm definitely open to trying some new things.

Therapist: One technique that can be really helpful is called "grounding." It's a way to anchor yourself in the present moment when you're feeling overwhelmed by emotions or negative thoughts. There are a few different ways to do it, but one simple method is to engage your senses. You might focus on five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. The idea is to really focus your attention on your sensory experience in the moment, rather than getting caught up in your thoughts.

Patient: That's interesting. I've heard of mindfulness, but I've never tried anything like that before. I can see how it could be helpful to just focus on what's around me instead of what's in my head.

Therapist: Mindfulness is definitely related to grounding. They both involve bringing your attention to the present moment. With grounding, the focus is specifically on your sensory experience as a way to anchor yourself. Would you be willing to give it a try now, just to get a feel for it? We can do it together.

Patient: Sure, I'm willing to give it a shot.

Therapist: Great. Let's start with five things you can see right now. Take a look around the room and notice five different things. They can be anything - objects, colors, textures. Just notice them without judging them as good or bad.

Patient: Okay, I see the clock on the wall, the pattern on the rug, the leaves on the plant in the corner, the books on the shelf, and the way the light is coming through the window.

Therapist: Good. Now, four things you can touch. It could be the fabric of your clothes, the surface you're sitting on, anything you can physically feel.

Patient: I can feel the softness of my sweater, the smoothness of the armrest on this chair, the texture of the worry stone I keep in my pocket, and the coolness of the metal on my necklace.

Therapist: Great. Now, three things you can hear. It could be sounds in the room, sounds outside, even the sound of your own breathing.

Patient: I can hear the ticking of the clock, the sound of the air conditioning, and a little bit of traffic noise from outside.

Therapist: Okay, two things you can smell. This one can be a bit trickier, but just notice any scents that are present, even if they're subtle.

Patient: I can smell the scent of the hand lotion I used earlier, and a faint smell of coffee from the mug on the table.

Therapist: And finally, one thing you can taste. It could be the taste in your mouth, or if you have a drink or a piece of candy with you, you could try that.

Patient: I don't have anything with me, but I can taste a hint of the toothpaste from when I brushed my teeth this morning.

Therapist: Good. So, what was it like to go through that exercise? How do you feel now compared to before we started?

Patient: It was actually kind of calming. I feel a bit more centered, I guess. Like I'm more in my body and less in my head.

Therapist: That's a great way to describe it. Grounding can be a really effective way to calm ourselves when we're feeling overwhelmed. It's something you can do anytime, anywhere, without anyone even knowing you're doing it. It can be a good addition to your Coping Card.

Patient: Yeah, I can definitely see myself using that. It's good to have different options, because sometimes one thing works better than another.

Therapist: Absolutely. It's all about having a toolbox of coping strategies you can pull from depending on the situation and how you're feeling. And the more you practice these techniques, the more automatic they become.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess it's like with anything - the more you do it, the easier it gets.

Therapist: Exactly. And speaking of practice, I'm wondering if we could spend a few minutes now reviewing how you've been doing with the Positive Data Log and thought records we've been working on. Those are also skills that get stronger with practice.

Patient: Sure, I've actually been meaning to talk to you about that. I've been trying to do the thought records, but I'm finding it really hard to come up with evidence against my negative thoughts. It's like I can see why they're not completely true, but I don't have any solid proof to back it up.
